item.title: Use of multi-linear regression and genetic algorithms to predict the boiling point of glycerol based solvents
item.author: adrianvenegasreynoso@gmail.com (Adrián Venegas Reynoso)
item.description: Introduction Linear regression is one of the most useful techniques used by analytical chemists, since it allows us to find relate a response variable $Y$ with a controlled variable $X$ through a mathematical expression: $$ Y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1 X_i + \varepsilon_i, i = 1,…,n, $$ where: $\beta_0$ is the intercept, $\beta_1$ the slope $\varepsilon_i$ the error in the measurement. As you can see, the previous equation has the subindex $i$, which means that each measured data point $Y_i$ can be associated with a data point $X_i$.

item.title: Use of Near-Infrared (NIR) Spectroscopy to measure the sugar content in fruits
item.author: adrianvenegasreynoso@gmail.com (Adrián Venegas Reynoso)
item.description: Overview Near-Infrared is the region of the electromagnetic that spans from 780 nm to 2500 nm. For a long time, it was regarded as the “garbage can” of spectroscopy, since spectral bands in this region are broad, of low intensity and hard to interpret.
